# Task

Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".



# Data

clean_column("My Column")

Here is the function you can use in Julia programming language:

```julia
function clean_column(col)
    return replace(lowercase(strip(col)), r"[ -]" => "_")
end
```
You can call this function with a string argument, as shown below:
```julia
clean_column("My Column")
```

This code works by first converting the column name to lower case (so that "My Column" becomes "my column"), then removing any leading or trailing white spaces using `strip(col)`, and replacing any spaces or hyphens with underscores using `replace(lowercase(strip(col)), r"[ -]" => "_")`. 

The `r"[ -]"` part of the regular expression means "a space or a hyphen". The `=>` operator is used to replace matched substrings, and `"_"` is the replacement string. This approach effectively replaces spaces and hyphens with underscores.
